messages.subject: Correction to Web Address for Battle Scroll of the Naval War during Imjin War
messages.msgSnippet: Please, use the following address for the picture: http://www.dkbnews.com/bbs/view.php?id=headlinenews&no=4356 or
messages.messageBody:
Please, use the following address for the picture:
http://www.dkbnews.com/bbs/view.php?id=headlinenews&no=4356

or
http://dc5.donga.com/zero/zboard.php?id=military&page=1&sn1=&divpage=15&banner=&sn=off&ss=on&sc=on&keyword=%ef%bf%bd%ef%bf%bd%ef%bf%bd%ef%bf%bd&select_arrange=headnum&desc=asc&no=97706&PHPSESSID=1cd65abe60eaf1adf77973b59e88e0df

--- Lee Changsub <knorr31@...> wrote:
>
> Dear Group:
> Hi, I came across a battle scroll of the Japanese
> and
> Korean Naval war during the Imjin War.(1592-98)
> The picture was drawn by a Japanese painter. An
> exact
> source and names could I not find it. But, I found
> the
> picture at
> http://www.dkbnews.com/img/2005/03/123/w1.jpg.
>
> The picture is pretty accurate in a description of
> the
> weaponery and battle uniforms of two countries
> during
> the war.
>
> This picture describes the battle where Admiral Lee
> Sun-Shin defeated 136 ships with only 12 ships
> immediately after a major defeat of the Korean Navy
> under another Korean Admiral with Admiral Lee
> himself
> imprisoned due to the political attack against him.
>
> Although I am origianlly a Korean national and am
> planning to become an American citizen, I personally
> admire the Japanese culture and outstanding martial
> tradition.
> Japanese and Koreans are most close relative to each
> other linguistically, culturally, and ethnically.
> I do believe that the prosperity of two countries
> and
> the stability of the North East Asia depends on how
> Japan and Korea cooperate and support each other
> because of their geographical proximity and ecnomic,
> poltical, and military interdependence.
>
> The past is the past. What lies ahead is our future
> and the future of our next generation.
>
>
>
>
> Sincerely,
>
>
>
>
> Changsub Lee
>
>
>
